Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Revealing Mammalian Biodiversity with Leech Blood Meals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Terrestrial leech blood meals are excellent at revealing rare and unknown mammal diversity. Researches have identified a variety of mammals by sampling blood meals of leeches, including species recently discovered, likely threatened, near threatened, and unknown to a sampling area (despite attempts to find individuals), as well as a cryptic species that requires DNA to identify. The substantial and growing scientific infrastructure and expertise in China make it ideal for forging life-long collaborations, while utilizing this new blood meal method to uncover cryptic biodiversity. Dr. Doug Yu at the Kunming Institute of Zoology in Yunnan Province, China will supervise this project. Yunnan is an exceptional target site for mammal conservation, as it is houses half of China's mammals, the majority of China's protected species, and is already a major focus for existing conservation programs. China is also known for an exceptional diversity and high abundance of terrestrial leeches, yet reconstructions of the terrestrial leech tree of life are largely devoid of Chinese samples.

This project will test three hypotheses: 1) blood meals are a novel, efficient tool for surveying and finding mammalian biodiversity in Yunnan; 2) terrestrial leeches display host specificity; and 3) Yunnan terrestrial leech biodiversity is vastly underestimated. DNA from leeches and their blood meals will be sequenced using amplicon based next-generation sequencing. Mammal hosts determined from these sequences will be compared to park checklists, testing this method's efficacy for surveying mammalian biodiversity. Leech host specificity will be tested using statistical analyses. The most extensively sampled terrestrial leech tree of life will be constructed, using sequences from this study and prior research, to test the accuracy of current classifications. This also will aid in identification of new species like the recently described Yunnan cave leech. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this EAPSI fellowship was to collect terrestrial leech specimens critical for the completion of dissertation work. With these specimens two major objectives are being completed: 1) reconstructing the evolutionary tree of terrestrial leeches in the family Haemadipsidae, while describing any new species found; and 2) determining mammal hosts in the areas surveyed by sequencing blood in the leech specimen’s digestive tract, providing further insight into the utility of this method in China. Furthermore, these complementary data will be used to assess host specificity of the leeches.

A variety of haemadipsid specimens were collected across sites in China. Collecting took place in both Yunnan and Hainan provinces. In Yunnan collecting focused in Xishuangbanna and Gaoligong Mountains, while Hainan collecting was focused in Yinggeling. Collections were made from 22 sites surveyed within these areas. Specimens comprise six species, summing to 1/3 of known Chinese haemadipsid diversity. Additionally, during my time in China I produced the most complete evolutionary tree of the Haemadipsidae. The resulting tree was well supported for the majority of relationships for the two-jawed leeches. These relationships portrayed a strong deviation from traditional classifications for most subfamilies and genera within the two-jawed leeches. This tree allowed for the confident revision of classification in this group. Specifically, the revision compresses numerous molecularly invalid genera into a single genus. This furthermore makes the genus more comparable in size and evolutionary distance to the other major haemadipsid genus. Furthermore a putative new species was found to be molecularly distinct. This new species was minute in size and to describe its internal morphology it was micro-CT scanned; it will be the first extant species described using this technology.

Relationships were less well resolved within the three-jawed haemadipsids, the lineage found in China. Specimens from China have been sorted by site and DNA has been extracted for representatives of all species from each site. DNA for the four genes commonly used in genetic studies of terrestrial leeches has been amplified. This DNA will be sequenced, helping to get a more accurate reconstruction of the evolutionary tree of the three-jawed haemadipsids. This will help resolve current areas of conflict in classification at the species and genus level. Following this work, samples will have their blood meals dissected. DNA sequencing of the blood will determine which mammals the leeches are feeding on. This technique will help to determine what mammals are in a given area. The technique has been successful in finding both known and unknown biodiversity in Vietnam.

This fellowship resulted in the formation of several collaborations, particularly with the host institute Kunming Institute of Zoology (KIZ). Lab members assisted with many aspects of my project. In exchange I was able to train a new lab technician in field techniques necessary for collecting leeches. Upon return to the US I taught high school students about the biology of leeches and how they are currently being utilized for the survey of mammals in difficult to survey areas or for difficult to survey species. Furthermore students were taught about the collecting and preservation techniques used in fieldwork and the molecular techniques utilized for biodiversity research.
